resources.string: FindComb
Choose the discriminative feature.
Maybe, interactions are discriminative.
Different features may have the same effect.
You are going to face a very difficult task. Be aware that us humans are bad at solving this type of problems. Machines, on the other hand, do very well.
Can you beat them?
There are healthy and sick individuals.
Each individual has features, represented by colors.
Choose the feature that is associated most with the disease.
You can also choose combinations of features.
Features may interact.
Either many features combined correlate with the disease...
... or different features have the same effect.
Complicated combinations are allowed.
Green and yellow have the same effect...
...and, in combination with red, are associated with the disease.
There is a penalty for the number of features you use.
There is a penalty if your rule does not govern all individuals.
Your time budget runs out quickly.
Correct configurations will add time to your budget.
Suboptimal configurations will add less time.
There is a penalty for bad configurations.
Customer 1
Customer 2
